NATIONAL ECONOMICS UNIVERSITY INSTITUTE OF ADVANCED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS | SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF VIETNAM Independence – Freedom – Happiness
COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,           ,            , 2023)
Bachelor of Software Engineering

- Title: Calculus                                      Code: CNTT1182E
- Credits: 3 (45 credit hours; 1 credit hour = 50 minutes of lecture)
- Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
- Lecture: 30 hrs
- Exercises on class: 15 hrs
- Exercise and discussion (Tutor): 15 hrs
- Self-study: 90 hrs.
- Parallel course(s): None
- Prerequisite course(s): None
- Department conducting the course:
- Faculty: Information Technology, R1310, 13th flr., Building A1, The National Economics University, 207 Giai Phong Road, Hai Ba Trung District, Hanoi, Vietnam.
- Lecturers:
- MA. Nguyễn Quỳnh Mai			 Email: mainq@neu.edu.vn
- PhD. Phạm Minh Hoàn			Email: 	hoanpm@neu.edu.vn
- Kind of the course:

Foundation □ | Foundation □ | Fundamental □ | Fundamental □
Compulsory □ | Elective □ | Compulsory □ | Elective □
- Course language: In English

This course provides basic concepts of numerical analysis; polynomial interpolation; function approximation. The module also provides knowledge about numerical methods in approximate calculation of derivatives and integrals, solution of equations, system of linear equations, and differential equations. Use the Matlab programming language to simulate the above methods.
This course also aims to train thinking skills and the ability to self-study related knowledge and technology by working independently as well as in groups. Students will be assigned group exercises to learn programming languages ​​to solve problems related to calculation methods and problems in the field of Information Technology.

[1].  Introduction to Numerical Analysis, J. Stoer and R. Bulirsch, Springer, 1992
[2].   Introduction to Numerical Analysis. S. Baska. India Institute of Technology Bombay

Table 4.1. Course Goals
Goal | Goals Description | PLOs | Proficiency scale
[1] | [2] | [3] | [4]
G1 | This course provides learners with knowledge about: calculation methods, types of errors; polynomial interpolation; function approximation; Numerical analysis in approximating derivatives and integrals; approximate methods of solving equations, systems of linear equations and differential equations. | PLO 1.3 PLO1.4 | T
G2 | This course guides learners on the skills to find and read documents by topic. Have communication, presentation and report writing skills in group exercises. Programming skills illustrate approximate methods of solving equations, systems of equations, derivatives, and integrals using the Matlab programming language. | PLO 2.1 | U
G3 | The course contributes to develope the ability to work independently and in groups, and to properly understand work responsibilities and professional ethics. | PLO 3.1 PLO3.4 | U

Table 5.1. Course learning outcomes
Goal | CLO | CLO Description | Teaching level (I,T,U)
[1] | [2] | [3] | [4]
G1 | CLO1.1 | Introduction to approximate solution methods; types of errors. Describe methods: polynomial interpolation, approximation of functions by the method of least squares, approximation of derivatives and integrals, approximation of equations, systems of linear equations and differential equations. | T
G1 | CLO1.2 | Apply solution methods to find approximate solutions of equations, systems of equations, ordinary differential equations, approximate derivatives, and definite integrals. | U
G1 | CLO1.3 | Apply knowledge of approximate solution methods combined with practice on the Matlab programming language to provide solutions to interpolation problems, find solutions of equations and systems of equations, approximate derivatives and definite integral. | U
G2 | CLO2.1 | Skills in searching, collecting, synthesizing, analyzing, presenting problems on approximate solutions | T
G2 | CLO2.2 | Have coordination skills to solve group assignments, ensuring the completion of team work on schedule. | U
G2 | CLO2.3 | Have skills in applying and combining knowledge of numerical methods in simulating problems in programming languages | U
G3 | CLO3.1 | Ability to read and learn materials on their own to complete assigned lessons and assignments | U
G3 | CLO3.2 | Have a sense of classroom discipline, comply with classroom rules, have a spirit of cooperation and personal responsibility for activities assigned by the instructor. | U

9. COURSE REQUIREMENTS AND EXPECTATION
9.1. Requirements for taking final /terminal exams
- Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
9.2. Requirements for attending classes
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
9.3. Requirements for in-class behaviour
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
